section.title: used to / get used to / would
section.sectiontitle: Use used to to talk about past habits and states that do not happen now.
section.text1a: I used to catch the bus to work but now I go by bike.
section.sectiontitle2: Note that in the negative and question form use does not finish with a -d.
section.text3a: She didn't use to be nearly so ambitious.
section.text4a: Did you use to enjoy travelling for your job?

section.title: <i>used to / get used to / would
section.sectiontitle: Use would to also talk about past habits but not past states.
section.text1a: When we were little, we would dress up and pretend to be kings and queens.
section.sectiontitle2: For past states use used to, not would.
section.text4a: Before I went on that diet, I used to be fat.

section.title: used to / get used to / would
section.sectiontitle: Use get used to to describe the process of becoming accustomed to a new situation. Note the spelling is always used with a -d.
section.text1a: We're getting used to living in a small village in the country but it's still a little strange.
section.text2a: I can't get used to leaving for work at 5.30 a.m.
section.sectiontitle2: Use be used to to say when you have become accustomed to a new situation. Note the spelling is always used with a -d.
section.text3a: She's used to being her own boss.
section.text4a: Do you think you are used to living in the USA now?
